Award.AwardTitle: RUI: Utilization of a Thio-Bromo Substitution Reaction for the Preparation of a New Class of ROMP Hydrogels
Award.AbstractNarration:
Hydrogels are polymeric networks that are not soluble in water but instead swell in the presence of water. Because of this property, they have broad applications in the biomedical fields. Professor Christopher Hobbs' group at Texas A&M University-Kingsville explores new routes toward the preparation of functional hydrogels. Specially, his research group develops a highly efficient and precious metal-free reaction for the synthesis and modification of hydrogels. This project provides interdisciplinary research experience to many underrepresented undergraduate students, delivering a vital stepping stone toward careers in fields of science, technology, engineering, and mathematics (STEM). Additionally, Professor Hobbs organizes Polymer Chemistry Workshops, in which high school teachers learn methods and experiments that can be used to introduce aspects of polymer chemistry in their science classes in the hopes of recruiting a new, diverse generation of young students to STEM fields.

This project focuses on the utilization of a facile, catalyst-free substitution reaction between thiols and alpha-bromo esters for the preparation of a new class of hydrogels. The process employs thio-bromo substitution reactions to convert alpha-bromoester-containing polynorbornenes and poly(oxanorbornene)s to polymers with functionality (e.g., hydroxyl, amino, and ionic groups) known to instill water-swellability to macromolecular architectures. Cross-linking of the resulting polymers with dithiols produces a new class of hydrogels. While the preparation of alpha-bromoester-containing polynorbornenes and poly(oxanorbornene)s by Ring Opening Metathesis Polymerization (ROMP) requires the use of a ruthenium catalyst, the conversion of these polymers to hydrogels involves metal-free reactions that minimize the use of precious metals. With the support from the NSF Macromolecular, Supramolecular and Nanochemistry Program, Professor Hobbs' group conducts research to examine the effectiveness of this synthetic approach and the dependence of the hydrogel properties on the polymeric backbone, side chain groups, and cross-linker identity.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Project Outcomes Report

Project Title: RUI: Utilization of a Thio-Bromo Substitution Reaction for the Preparation of a New Class of ROMP Hydrogels

Project Number 1744700

Institutions: Texas A&M University-Kingsville, Sam Houston State University

PI: Christopher Hobbs

This grant was awarded in 2016 to a team led by Prof. Christopher Hobbs whose work was aimed at the exploration of new methods for the preparation and chemical modification of polymers and hydrogels using simple and "green" (environmentally safer) chemical transformations.

Polymers are long chains of individual molecules that are linked together in specific ways. The way in which these molecules are linked defines the structure and properties of the polymer. The work of Hobbs' team (composed mainly of undergraduate students, many of whom are from underrepresented groups) has involved exploring new ways to make and modify linear polymers (materials in which the molecules are linked in a straight chain), graft polymers (linear polymers with long chains of molecules extending outward), and polymer hydrogels (materials that are insoluble in water but swell in its presence). 

This funding has allowed the team to synthesize new hydrogels by linking individual polymer chains together, forming networks that swell when submerged in water. These types of materials are important for many applications, including medicinal chemistry where they can be used for drug delivery systems. The team has designed hydrogels that can undergo decomposition in water in a predetermined timeframe (anywhere from 1 to 14 days), that will be used as drug delivery agents in the future. The team has also developed new graft polymers, some of which are useful as drug delivery agents. This works because the polymers were designed to form micelle structures in water, similar to soap, in which the inner core of the micelle contained a drug molecule. For example, it was shown that cellular uptake of paclitaxel (a chemotherapy agent sold commercially as Taxol) was 1.5 times higher using these micelles than using the drug alone. In the course of their work, the team also developed a new method for the synthesis of flame-resistant polymers, an important endeavor considering that polymers and plastics encountered in everyday life are inherently flammable. Students working in Hobbs' laboratory have developed a simple method for the inclusion of phosphorus atoms into a polymer chain. This allows for the polymer to "self-extinguish" upon exposure to fire by forming a protective phosphorus char which stops the spread of the flame. 

This team has also explored new ways in which chemical reactions can be carried out and applied to polymer synthesis and modification. Most chemical reactions are carried out in glass flasks while mixing in organic solvents. Unfortunately, these solvents are non-renewable, as they are derived from Earth's finite petroleum reserves. Methods to perform experiments without the need for them is an important goal because it reduces our dependence on petroleum and reduces waste. Hobbs' team has explored new ways to carry out polymer syntheses and modifications with little to no required solvent. One method involves physically grinding reagents together in a ball mill. The mechanical force of the milling provides the energy needed to accomplish a chemical reaction (so-called "mechanochemistry") without solvents. Additionally, students were able to carry out these reactions under a continuously flowing stream by pumping reagents through a tubular reaction system, instead of using a flask. This so-called "continuous flow" system allows for reactions to be conducted quickly and efficiently. For example, Hobbs? lab has shown that linear polymers can be synthesized in a matter of seconds using this method. 

Funding from this grant was also used for outreach in the form of presentations and workshops for area middle-and high school science teachers from smaller, rural school districts that are composed of large groups of minority students. Unfortunately, many of these districts lack the resources that are found in larger, wealthier schools, so their ability to effectively teach STEM (science, technology, engineering and mathematics) classes may be affected. This workshop was designed to provide knowledge and ideas of how polymer science can easily be adapted and taught in their classrooms with the minimum amount of resources. Examples included: exploring biodegradable plastics using inexpensive cups purchased online, making plastics from milk, making slime from borax, and investigating different properties of polymers using Styrofoam packing peanuts and baby diapers.
